instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.PPVCORE_GPU: What is PPVCORE_GPU? This is the main power rail for the GPU. This is required for the GPU to turn on so you can get image on the display. .
definitions.LCD_PWR_EN: What is LCD_PWR_EN? LCD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip that supplies power to the LCD screen to turn on..
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Chime, No Image
threads.message:
I got on the table an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that draws 1.4 amps, has chime and MS light, but fans ramp up to max RPM and backlight comes on immediately when laptop is powered on. This board has clear signs of previous work on <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR>, <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> and <CHIP>U5550</CHIP>. There was flux all around <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> and <CHIP>U5550</CHIP> and after I cleaned it off I could see the poor soldering job that was left. I re-soldered both chips but that didn't change anything. <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL> is .7V and 10.3 Ohms to gnd. I have a working version of this board for comparison and the working board is 34 ohms to gnd. 

<SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PP5VR3V3_SW_LCD</SIGNAL>: 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Chime, No Image
threads.message: Those reported voltages were measured both before the re-soldering and after by the way.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Chime, No Image
threads.message:
CPU should be good, if you get chime.
Confirm if board has USB activity after 30s and doesn't get stuck.

Did you resolder <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Chime, No Image
threads.message:
Confirmed chime
USB: Solid light, no activity
I did re-solder <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Chime, No Image
threads.message:
If board gets stuck, there could be GPU problem.

I hope you've properly checked the USB activity.
Read here, just in case...
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Chime, No Image
threads.message: Ok, yeah, confirmed by plugging in my USB boot drive with bright red LED into working machines
